Day 22: It is incredible how much better everything goes when I have actual traction between my feet and the floor.

Yoga, in general, works so much better when it's not a fight. And so often it is a fight: fighting my own tiredness and executive function to get to the mat in the first place, fighting my own brain to focus and not get too frustrated when there's something I can't do right away, fighting my own body to try and get it to move right. Fighting my feet and my balance and my pose and my slippery living room rug to stay upright in Warrior or Star Pose. And I can fight, and I can even win sometimes, and I gain something when I do, strength and stubbornness and workout, but--god, how much better it all is when it's not a fight at all.

I think, more than anything, that's what I've been discovering this journey. 'Renew' is a good theme for today, when I'm remembering my intention from day one, which was never to be very very good at this, but only to keep coming back and keep trying. I think I thought, on January 1st, that that meant trying harder the next day when I'd lost the fight, as I inevitably sometimes would. I think now maybe it means learning to back down, back away, pause and come back and renew when I find the direction things don't have to be a fight from to begin with.

It means previewing the videos so I know what poses I'm in for and don't have to struggle to figure them out mid-practice. It means rolling the rug back or buying a yoga mat so my feet actually stick to the floor instead of trying to stay upright purely with thigh strength and determination. It means jumping on the moment in the middle of the morning when my body wants to get up and move, rather than forcing it. Some days it means no yoga at all, and some days it means coming back and being more proud and satisfied with that than guilty.

Eight more days to this sequence. Maybe I'll go back and try 'Home' again when this is done. Maybe I'll move on to something else. I'll keep going.
